message_1: Let P be a proposition. If P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R. Prove that if P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R, using natural deduction.
message_2:
To prove that if P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R using natural deduction, we will use the rules of implication elimination (→E) and implication introduction (→I). Here's the proof:

1. (P → Q) (Assumption)
2. (Q → R) (Assumption)
3. P (Assumption)
4. Q (1, 3, →E) (From P → Q and P, we can deduce Q)
5. R (2, 4, →E) (From Q → R and Q, we can deduce R)
6. (P → R) (3-5, →I) (From the assumption P, we deduced R, so we can introduce the implication P → R)

So, we have shown that if P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R using natural deduction.
